APIs in their current sense evolved from the original API
Local APIs originated as a way to build systems (i.e., one big thing)
Network APIs were invented decades ago but nobody found the silver bullet
Web APIs are a loose and evolving collection of principles and patterns
Languages become necessary when coordination is required
Human language is a result of improving ecological fitness
Human written language is a result of new organizational challenges
Same problems/approaches/answers like other language problems
Domain-only: Domains figure out their problems and their languages
Universal: Find the universal grammar and use it everywhere
Hybrid: Establish principles and patterns but avoid überformats
Languages both establish and cross domain boundaries
System/ecosystem boundaries are blurry
System/ecosystem perspective is a question of perspective
APIs provide a foundation for communications in an ecosystem
Internal: Value is in system changeability
External: Value is in system interoperability
API discussions should always be aware of both perspectives
Separate internal/external API strategies are counter-productive

ul.li: Many environments change at increasing velocities
Economics change
Incentives change
Technologies change
Organizations are pushed to better handle change
They have to become better at reacting to external changes
They have to become better at executing internal changes
They have to become better at embracing changing
External: Participating in the API economy becomes increasingly beneficial
Interfacing with customers/partners becomes easier
The number of API-ready customers/partners keeps increasing
The network effect guarantees for the trend to continue
Internal: Being able to plan and execute changing quickly improves fitness
Traditionally, IT is perceived as a sluggish and heavyweight
Increasingly, IT becomes the lube for the organizational machinery
Additionally, IT can allow completely new classes of business models
Having an API strategy becomes increasingly important
Organizations have executed on this for a long time (Amazon API memo: 2002)
Organizations share experiences and tooling around API strategies
Using APIs becomes less of an if and more of a how
Business pushes IT to make sure strategy can be executed quickly
IT can leverage others as justification and leaders
Internal: Using APIs to break up monolithic systems
Focus on systems/software engineering and better modularization

li.q: Turn a system into an ecosystem.

ul.li: Use Private APIs as a way to reduce tight coupling
External: Using APIs to build up ecosystems
Focus on distributed/decentralized systems and better connectivity

li.q: Enable an ecosystem by loosely coupling systems.

ul.li: Use Public APIs as a way to (better) interface with partners/public
Both views are complementary and mostly a difference in perspective

presentation.title: API Platforms and API Landscape Management
presentation.toc: This presentation looks at how to establish API platforms, and how to use them as a starting point to establish, cultivate, and evolve a shared practice of API design and management.

slide.title: Looking for a good API Strategy? Look at the Web!

ul.li: Problem focus over solution focus
Problems are addressed by building capabilities with standardized interfaces
Solutions are created/managed by those who solve the problems
Platform diversity over landscape homogeneity
Solution providers pick platforms based on their preferences
Platforms evolve and so does the platform landscape as a whole
Solutions and platforms are completely decoupled
Solutions are looking at what service to provide
Platforms are concerned with how to implement the solution
Designed to provide shared tooling
Tooling becomes the backdoor for coupling creep
Resist the urge to provide an API platform
Ignoring one of the two major API value propositions
APIs are valuable because they decouple service users and providers
APIs are valuable because they decouple service implementations
Designed to use shared languages
Communications/coupling can only happen through APIs
Anything that needs to be shared must be openly communicated
Satisfying the two major API value propositions
APIs are valuable because they decouple service users and providers
APIs are valuable because they decouple service implementations
Importing code means coupling with the code
Code that does not communicate creates no external coupling
Code that does communicate creates external coupling
Code that communicates via a visible API creates acceptable coupling
Code that communicates via hidden channels creates unacceptable coupling

ol.li: The first rule of MSA club is that you can only communicate via APIs
The second rule of MSA club is that you can only communicate via APIs
The third rule of MSA club: if you communicate via side channels, you are out
The fourth rule of MSA club is that if you need communications, design a language

ul.li: Apply well-known Patterns for Robust Extensibility
Meaningful core semantics: Create a useful minimal language
Well-defined extension points: Allow the language to evolve
Well-defined processing model: Say how to behave when encountering extensions
Loose coupling encourages service changes and replacements
Design for service changes: Non-breaking changes as the primary goal
Design for service replacements: Languages remain intact across implementations

presentation.title: API Contracts
presentation.toc: The current focus around API documentation is on the technical side and how to describe an existing service so that it can be consumed. However, documentation goes beyond the simple technical interface description and covers many non-functional aspects. This presentation is an overview of this broader view of what API contracts and documentation are about, and how organizations can manage the production and publication of this more comprehensive documentation.

ul.li: Enterprise IT has discovered Web Architecture: They call it Microservices!
Visibility is a key issue for making the webby enterprise work
Enterprise IT still needs control over the evolving service landscape
Being more cooperative will help the success of webby approaches
Design Instrumentation allows better service landscaping
Think of it as accessibility checkers for the service web
Balancing speed and safety requires understanding what you are balancing
Spontaneous interactions without prior agreement
Surfing the Web means Surfing the Uniform Interface
Shared assumptions mean seamless transition between services/sites
The human Web hardcodes assumptions into browser capabilities
The human Web has advantages over the service Web
Painful memory of browser wars and their effect on Web development
Humans are highly adaptable to deal with non-technology changes
The Web of today is very different from the Web we had
HTML5 has 133 current specs and counting
HTTP has 187 well-known header fields and counting
Surfing the Web means Surfing an evolving surface
How to keep track of the changing landscape?
Run-time instrumentation helps understanding what is really happening
Design-time instrumentation allows some level of self-declaration
Identify design patterns based on shared concepts
Treating concepts as a flat space leaves out many details
Deeper models can still be based on the shared concept surface
The uniform interface evolves and so should attempts to track it
New Web Concept values are defined/created constantly
New Web Concepts appear less frequently

li.q: Make any model as shallow as possible, model depth tightly couples and makes model matching and mapping much harder.

ul.li: What is the Uniform Interface of the Web?
It depends on who you are asking
It depends on when you are asking
There is probably a relatively agreed-upon core and many extension areas
Create a composable view of the uniform interface that evolves and extends
Model as little as you can get away with
Create a common core that everybody can start with
Encourage evolution and extension
Concepts are established by defining/documenting them
The most popular ones are defined and documented in standards
Many concepts allow private uses of their namespace
Many specifications establish more than one concept
Solving a problem often requires more than just one concept
The specification established the domain that matters for the concept
Specifications (and services) may also depend on existing concepts
APIs should describe themselves as part of the API
Machine-readable about pages for API concepts
Controlled/published by APIs but useable by anybody
First proposals/projects are emerging
APIs.json only defines a format (description)
Pivio focuses on the tooling (submission and indexing)
Effective landscaping needs languages and tooling
Languages define what you are doing
Tooling helps with how it can be done
New tooling can be built only if a well-defined language exists
Reuse existing Web concepts as much as possible
Languages are easier to learn and use when they reuse established concepts
JSON Home Documents might be a good starting point
Extend the format or link from it with well-defined link relations
Define the language with robust extensibility in mind
Meaningful core semantics so that useful tools can be built
Extension model so that it is clear how to extend the core language
Processing model so that it is clear how to safely process the format
Tooling can only use the description format
Conventions around how the format is used in the landscape
Push vs. pull and minimal behavioral standards
Tooling can automate (part of) the service approval process
Collaborative landscaping makes it easier to build useful tooling
Services that grow in the garden will make honest statements
Adversarial landscapes need a lot more work to prevent misuse

presentation.title: API Change Management
presentation.toc: APIs are designed, developed, evolve, and eventually get decommissioned. There are both design and management challenges to this, so that one the one hand API producers and consumers are loosely coupled, but on the other hand there is a design in place that minimizes breakage in a large landscape of APIs.

ul.li: Version numbers have an almost mythical role in IT
But often they are only useful for signaling continuity or breakage points
Most things work or break in a binary way (or simply refuse to even try)
Compatibility comes in two basic flavors (one easier, one harder)
Backwards compatibility means to work with older components
Forward compatibility means to work with more advanced components
The Web has good rules to support both compatibility types
Backwards compatibility New browser accessing older content
Forward compatibility: Old browser accessing newer content

img.title: Roy Fielding (@fielding): 'The reason to make a real REST API is to get evolvability … a "v1" is a middle finger to your API customers, indicating RPC/HTTP (not REST)'

ul.li: Planning for evolution means to reduce pain in the future
No immediate benefits other than doing the right thing
Modest effort when part of the API design process and culture
Extensibility should be part of the API design culture
Each API must have and document a plan for API evolution
Extensibility should be made easy for API consumers
Provide test cases that simulate correct/incorrect API extensions
Provide feature flags so that services can enter test mode
The core of the API allows clients to have meaningful interactions
The starting point of an API should be meaningful and complete
The core of the API is robust over time
Anything that is added to the core does not change the core semantics
Anything that is not part of the core can be safely ignored
mustIgnore semantics allow safe interactions beyond closely coordinated groups
APIs should be clear about where extensions are allowed
API metamodels often decide where (potential) extension points are
API schemas/definitions should further narrow down where extensions are allowed
API tests can make sure that the extension points are properly implemented
Extensions in allowed places are ignored and tests should succeed
Extensions in other places should raise errors about malformed content
Extension points are interesting to support in generic software
Monitoring can report which and where extensions are being used
Libraries can make it easy to create/parse extension data
Extensions are well-defined and their handling is well-defined as well
Extension points make it clear where to expect extensions
Processing models make it clear what to do with extensions
mustIgnore is a popular and good choice for extension processing
Some formats allow extensions to declare their processing model (such as mustUnderstand)
HTML has a rule of ignoring unknown elements but processing their content
How to learn about extensions is a different matter
If an API evolves along a single path it may be as simple as looking along that path
If an API is used in more complex ways a registry may be a way to find extensions
Versioning may be necessary when the extension model is not working anymore
Three main ways how to distinguish between versions on the service surface
Make version numbers part of the resource URI: http://example.org/api/v2/
Use specific HTTP headers: API-Version: 2.0.0
Use media types: Accept: application/vnd.example.org.v2+json
All of these have side-effects which have to be balanced
New URIs change resource identity which may result in data integration problems
Custom headers are specific for a service and hard to see/support in the general Web fabric
Media types often are not used by APIs or the clients consuming them
Most APIs choose URI-based versioning and introduce new API identity
Versioning at this level is little more than keeping the API brand
Version numbers can be used in URI path or in the domain name
Semantic Versioning standardizes the meaning of version numbers
Version numbers follow the MAJOR.MINOR.PATCH pattern and the following rules
increase MAJOR version for incompatible API changes
increase MINOR version for adding functionality in a backwards-compatible manner
increase PATCH version for making backwards-compatible bug fixes
Mostly about how to name implementation artifacts and of limited use for APIs
Exposing detailed version/patch information is a potential security risk
No behavioral benefit other than allowing clients to raise errors and stop working
API change management becomes increasingly important
Microservices optimize for quick design/deployment/development/decommissioning
Even in MSA-land there are Experience APIs meant to deliver some API stability
APIs can change in terms of features and will be decommissioned at some point
Robust extensibility helps to facilitate non-breaking API changes
Hypermedia helps as a pattern to extend extensibility beyond data models
Semantic versioning may be used to keep track of API changes
HTTP Sunsetting can be used to signal upcoming sunsets on the HTTP level
Always follow the why/what/how triad for all platform management
Why: Some services/consumers are interested in how an API will change
What: Follow principles/patterns/protocols to manage/expose API changes
How: Support tooling/services to implement and test platform principles
API Description guidelines may ask for change management documentation
Requirement: Can be as simple as making documentation discoverable on deploy
Resolution: Can be as simple as stating that there is no change management
Discoverability and machine-readability are different issues
Making description resources discoverable is easy and can be validated during deployment
Every API entering the landscape does make change management documentation discoverable
For some classes of APIs/services additional requirements may be put in place
One possible requirement is that Public APIs must support Sunset
Services must document/describe the support of Sunset
Services may implement Sunset any way they like
The simplest option may be Sunset policies on a gateway

presentation.title: Microservices Benefits and Transition Strategies
presentation.toc: Microservices have a value proposition side to them (what to get out of them), but also a cost side (what it takes to transition and execute a microservices strategy). This presentation looks at the balance between these issues, and how to start a journey towards microservices.

ul.li: Build modularized components that can be scaled individually
Monitoring allows insights into system status and load
Rapid Provisioning allows to react quickly when new capacity is required
Rapid Deployment means simple ways to develop/test/start/scale services
Microservice implementations are more flexible than integrated approaches
Scaling can be done per service instead of scaling bigger deployment units
Code can be retired more easily by removing services from deployment
Fewer unintended side-effects since all interactions are through APIs
IT capabilities and management often are not aligned
Capabilities are growing and business demands are growing as well
Management becomes complex and impacts execution speed
There is a difference in separating interfaces and implementations
Interfaces are useful for accessing capabilities
Implementations must support easy modifications and additions
The first wave of API focus (SOA) focused on interfaces only
Focusing on APIs as business-aligned capabilities is a necessary first step
Agility suffers when implementations are not business-aligned
Conway's Law means that changing implementation structure can be hard

slide.title: Conway's Law
slide.blockquote: Any organization that designs a system (defined broadly) will produce a design whose structure is a copy of the organization's communication structure. (Mel Conway)

ul.li: SOAP-style SOA are traditional IT monoliths exposing some capabilities
MSA #1 goal is to create a loosely coupled service landscape
Shared data storage creates coupling
Shared infrastructure creates coupling
Shared libraries create coupling
Loose coupling allows to pick the right tool for the job
Loose coupling allows to refactor/retire as required
Loose coupling blurs the public/partner/private lines
Using APIs is one of the few overlaps between SOAP-style SOA and MSA
Decouple implementations and not just interfaces
Velocity is determined by how hard it is to make changes
The biggest problem is not access to capabilities but capability agility
Providing access to capabilities is better than doing nothing
Agile management of the capability landscape goes further than that
Microservices apply Web architecture to Enterprise IT
Implementation details are completely invisible to service users
Service consumption only uses well-defined and uniform interfaces

img.title: By Lachlan Donald from Melbourne, Australia (Sharpest tool in the shed) [CC BY 2.0 (http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/2.0)], via Wikimedia Commons

ul.li: SOAP's answer to service discovery was UDDI
The biggest failure of the SOAP Web Services stack
Allowing only one specific kind of service design
Focusing on the function signature as a service's main description
Building directories from carefully described and categorized entries
Feels like the Yahoo! of service discovery: The one true model approach
What does a Google of Service Discovery look like?
Starting from services, find available description/documentation resources
Index description/documentation resources for subsequent discovery
Add support for additional description/documentation formats as required
MSA is all about making services more independent and self-contained
Discovery should follow the same pattern: Avoid centralization, be polyglot
Decentralized discovery is based on pulling/crawling diverse data

ol.li: Start by finding available description/documentation resources
Process these based on supported description/documentation formats
Increase support if required by the evolving ecosystem
Provide discovery services based on the resulting service ecosystem snapshot

ul.li: Added benefit: Reality-based view on description/documentation/service ecosystem
Changing implies a one-time activity
Changeable implies an intrinsic property

blockquote.p:
Don't focus on what to change into;
Focus on embracing change as your mode of existence.

ul.li: Preserve: Functional core and business foundations
Nourish: Ability to change and situational awareness
Agile moves from an IT approach to a business approach
Individuals and interactions over processes and tools
Working software over comprehensive documentation
Customer collaboration over contract negotiation
Responding to change over following a plan
Manage access to old/new capabilities through a router or gateway
Transitioning is a management process old/new should be unaware of
Data sync/update is a separately managed process
Sophistication and cost of sync/update depends on consistency requirements
When one of the services disappears sync/update can be removed
Manage/monitor transition of service replacement
At some point in time decommissioning may be the most economical option
Until then the strangled monolith is the best case scenario
Remove red tape and embrace diversity
Business environments change faster than ever
Common question: How to change into a more successful organization
Better question: How to become an organization that is better at changing
The Web succeeded because it out-innovated everything else
Permissionless decentralized innovation
Data-driven decisions (traffic drives visibility and success)
Continuous change enabled through loose coupling

slide.title: Organizational Changes
slide.blockquote: Any organization that designs a system (defined broadly) will produce a design whose structure is a copy of the organization's communication structure. (Mel Conway)

ul.li: Learn from all of Conway's laws

ol.li: Support continuous process (Be able to do it over)
Improve team independence (Interdependent teams create interdependent systems)
Keep project scope small (Big problems/systems tend to shape-shift)

ul.li: Embrace change and start changing today
Start small and learn by doing
MSA management is about empowering
MSA creates an environment that is designed to be change-friendly
MSA technologies allow teams to deliver as fast as possible
APIs allows teams/partners to access new products as easily as possible
Microservices are all about how to implement services
APIs are all about how to interact with services
Microservices are an implementation detail from the API perspective
Microservice-implemented APIs might exhibit certain properties
Changing more often because of faster implementation cycles
More diverse API landscapes because of more autonomy
Smaller scope because of solutions targeted at specific problems
API consumers just use an API and not a Microservice API
Microservice API design is no different from API design in general
Tighter coupling may be acceptable for vertical scenarios (BFF pattern)
Balancing autonomy/diversity and coherence/usability is necessary
Microservices should have freedom to design their APIs
API design should be driven by design culture and patterns
Microservices strategy needs to distill/document/distribute design patterns
Be explicit about openness and extensibility
Provide glue that makes combining services easy
At the minimal level, always use global, unique, and persistent identifiers
Consider using hypermedia as a way to support service orchestration
Be explicit about how services signal end-of-life
MSA promotes agility (API designs should evolve)
MSA promotes diversity (in design and implementation)
MSA means more services (and the need for good DX across them)
With MSA comes the need for a mature API strategy
